title: Coke vs Pepsi
question_text:
Years ago, Pepsi wanted to show it was more popular than Coke.
So, Pepsi went around the country to various shopping centers giving people both colas to taste and tried to see if they knew the difference. Assuming that people do not know the difference (so $p=0.5$) if $64$ people came by to take the test, and $40$ seemed to know the difference, does this show it is likely true that people could tell the difference between Coke and Pepsi? Say "yes" or "no" and explain why using appropriate calculations.

choices.text:
No. With a mean of
32
and a standard deviation of
16
, we would expect to find
16
to
48
people on average to taste the difference.
40
falls within this range so it is likely they can not taste the difference.

No. With a mean of
32
and a standard deviation of 4, we would expect to find
28
to
36
people on average to taste the difference.
40
just is not that much higher and is not unusual so the people probably could not taste the difference.

Yes. With both the mean and the standard deviation equal to
16
, we would expect to find up to
32
people on average who could taste the difference. Since
40
is higher than
32
, then it is likely that they can taste the difference.

Yes. With a mean of
16
and a standard deviation of
4
, we would expect to find up to
20
people on average who could taste the difference.
40
is well above this so it is likely they can taste the difference.

Yes. With a mean of
32
and a standard deviation of 4, we would expect to find
28
to
36
people on average to taste the difference.
40
is
2

32
so it is likely they can taste the difference.
